Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: High-Efficiency Mid-Infrared Diode Lasers Incorporating Novel Metallic Nanoparticle-Enhanced Tunnel Junctions

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this research is to address a fundamental issue that pervades modern optoelectronic and photovoltaic devices: power conversion efficiency. The efficiency of highperformance photonic devices is typically limited by a combination of electrical resistance and optical absorption. The approach of this research is to combine photonics with nanotechnology to dramatically enhance the performance of lasers that emit in the mid-infrared portion of the electromagnetic spectrum. Such laser sources will find manifold applications in medicine, emissions monitoring, communications, etc.

Intellectual Merit: Recent advances in mid-infrared diode lasers are hampered by the optical absorption of free holes, which increases power consumption and degrades performance. This interdisciplinary approach couples nanostructured materials science with semiconductor physics to surmount this intrinsic limitation. Semimetallic nanostructures offer the capability to dramatically reduce the number of free holes that are required in edge emitting diode lasers, substantially reducing the optical loss, and enhancing power conversion efficiency.

Broader Impact: This research will produce a transformative photonic device paradigm that is applicable to a broad range of other problems in solid state lighting, solar power generation, and green computing/communications. The effort will integrate the proposed research with courses and outreach activities, exposing hundreds of talented students at the elementary, high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels to cutting edge photonics and nanoscience research to inspire them to pursue science and engineering careers. This work will also develop an undergraduate research program in photonicsfor women and underrepresented minorities.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have worked on developing a particular type of laser that emits mid-infrared light (beyond what the human eye can perceive), which are needed for many emerging applications including emissions monitoring, chemical/biological materials detection, non-invasive cancer detection, as well as for self-driving cars.  Specifically, we developed record performance lasers and worked towards an entirely new way to build these lasers, which should improve performance further.  Inserting a device called a tunnel junction, which uses quantum mechanics to effectively transform current carried by negatively charged electrons into current carried by positively charged particles, creates an entirely new way to reduce unwanted absorption of the laser light within the laser structure. This, in turn, allows more laser light to escape and be used for useful applications.  To produce this effect, we developed methods to insert crystalline metallic nanoparticles into the laser structure, without degrading the critical part of the laser that emits the light.

This project provided hands-on research opportunities for several Ph.D. students, undergraduates, high school students, and high school teachers.  We were also active in a number of outreach activities to the general public, mainly targeting primary and middle school students.  For example, in collaboration with Dr. Mitch Pryor in Mechanical Engineering, the PI co-hosted the Austin Children’s Museum summer camps periodically. Camps are ~25-30 children, typically between ages 6-8 years; several of the camps are all-girls. We provided a tour of the cleanroom fabrication facility and hands-on activities in the robotics lab, with the theme being working with robots and then learning how we build their brains. The PI introduced a hands-on component to the cleanroom tour. The PI’s research group also participated extensively in Science Thursdays at the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum, which offers free hands-on demos to the public related to various scientific principles (e.g. buoyancy).

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We have worked on developing a particular type of laser that emits mid-infrared light (beyond what the human eye can perceive), which are needed for many emerging applications including emissions monitoring, chemical/biological materials detection, non-invasive cancer detection, as well as for self-driving cars. Specifically, we developed record performance lasers and worked towards an entirely new way to build these lasers, which should improve performance further. Inserting a device called a tunnel junction, which uses quantum mechanics to effectively transform current carried by negatively charged electrons into current carried by positively charged particles, creates an entirely new way to reduce unwanted absorption of the laser light within the laser structure. This, in turn, allows more laser light to escape and be used for useful applications. To produce this effect, we developed methods to insert crystalline metallic nanoparticles into the laser structure, without degrading the critical part of the laser that emits the light. This project provided hands-on research opportunities for several Ph.D. students, undergraduates, high school students, and high school teachers. We were also active in a number of outreach activities to the general public, mainly targeting primary and middle school students. For example, in collaboration with Dr. Mitch Pryor in Mechanical Engineering, the PI co-hosted the Austin Children?s Museum summer camps periodically. Camps are ~25-30 children, typically between ages 6-8 years; several of the camps are all-girls. We provided a tour of the cleanroom fabrication facility and hands-on activities in the robotics lab, with the theme being working with robots and then learning how we build their brains. The PI introduced a hands-on component to the cleanroom tour. The PI?s research group also participated extensively in Science Thursdays at the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum, which offers free hands-on demos to the public related to various scientific principles (e.g. buoyancy).
